title: What is the limit of selective breeding? - Quora

response.answer_text: Besides Andrea Worthington’s fine answer, are morphological and species limitations. A Great Dane and a Shi-Tsu could theoretically produce viable offspring, but I'm not sure it would work without artificial insemination. Likewise, people have tried to mate different species with varied success, but that can obviously be a limitation.

One limit is inbreeding which leads to an amplification of genetic defects. Selective breeding requires careful selection of parents to prevent genetic defects in the offspring one is trying to cultivate.
Your question is too ambiguous to really answer. But, the limit would likely be when there is no or very little genetic variation left in the organism being bred selectively.
The limit is changing with our ability to nurture genetic freaks, like the English bulldog and broiler chicken. We can now also select GM individuals.
